resources.string: Seems that your device isn\'t properly rooted
You have to grant at least Storage and Contacts permissions to make t-ui work
t-ui has not the permissions to do this
Lock the screen on double tap
Can\'t toggle Airplane Mode on 4.2+ Android Version
Cant\'t write here. It\'s a file
The selected file is a directory
An unknown I/O error has occurred
Couldn\'t stop the player. Force stop t-ui from settings
Music folder doesn\'t exist, or doesn\'t contain mp3 files.\nYou should set a new one in the settings.txt file
Too many arguments, try passing only needed

Francesco Andreuzzi, ITA, Programmer, andreuzzi.francesco@gmail.com 

Luke Winward, USA, Designer 

Open Source Libraries: 
andre1299-comparestring 
Apache commons-io
Print alias that are currently saved in \"sdcard\"/t-ui/alias.txt

Manage your apps 
Usage apps [option] [app name] 

[option] can be: 
-h [app name] -> hide the app 
-uh [app name] -> unhide the app 
-sh -> show hidden apps 
no option -> list your apps 

Example: 
apps -h whatsapp

Copy one or more files to a folder 
Usage: [su] cp [files] [folder] 

Example: 
su cp fool.txt fool2.png myFolder 
cp myFile.txt myFolder
Toggle mobile data. Will always turn off it if WiFi is active

Print a list of available commands at this moment, or informations about a command 
Usage: help command 

Example: 
help search

Move one or more files to a folder 
Usage: [su] mv [files] [folder] 

su mv fool.txt fool2.png myFolder 
mv fool.txt myFolder
Play the next track in the queue

Play a specific track 
Usage: listen trackname 

Example: 
play back in black 

(The track has to be located in your Music Folder)
Help T-UI with a positive rate (or negative, I don\'t know)\t;)
Uninstall t-ui automatically. \n\nMake sure you have another Launcher!
Restart t-ui and load modified values

Remove a file: 
Usage: [su] rm [files] 

Example: 

su rm fool.txt fool2.png 
rm Downloads/fool.txt

Search something somewhere 
Usage: search [option] something 

[option] can be: 
-g -> (Google Search) 
-p -> (Google Play Store) 
-f -> (Files) 
-y -> (YouTube) 

Example: 
search -p T-UI

Share a file 
Usage: share pathToFile 

Example: 
share fool.jpg
Get infos about battery charge, wifi status and mobile data
Print informations about the current track
Print all of the tracks in your music folder

Uninstall an application 
Usage: uninstall appName OR packageName 

Example: 
uninstall dropbox

Change the current directory 
Usage: cd path 

Example: 
cd /storage/sdcard1/DCIM

Open a file with the default application 
Usage: open pathToFile 

Example: 
open docs/fool.txt

Print a list of the files in a directory 
Usage: ls directory 

Example: 
ls Downloads
Tap anywhere to learn how to use T-UI

Keep in mind that T-UI uses CompareString library. So, you can mistype the application name, or type ONLY A PART of the name. 
For example: 

>> inagrm 
Launching com.instagram.android 
>> whats 
Launching com.whatsapp

You can play your music from t-ui. Just use those commands: 

next ==> Play the next song in the queue 
previous ==> Play the previous song in the queue 
stop ==> Stop the player 
listen ==> Play a specific track 
track ==> Print informations about the **current** track 
tracks ==> List your songs 

Your songs have to be in mainstorage/Music.

T-UI is completely customizable, you can set your personal colors, preferences, disable/enable features, and do many other things. You just need to use the command 

>>tuisettings 

Then you can edit the file which get opened. To change a value, just delete everything on the right of the "=" character, and replace it with your own value.

T-UI comes with many commands which will simplify your Android experience. Some examples are uninstall, call, search. 
You can get a detailed list of them using the command 
>>help. 

You can also get specific informations about a command typing 
>>help command_name 

You can also use default Linux Shell commands built in your Android device. You can get a list of them using the command 
>>shellcommands

Alias are abbreviation that can be used as entire commands. 

To create an alias: 
1. Use the command "aliasfile" 
2. Choose a name for your alias (everything you want) 
3. Decide what your alias will mean 
4. Go to a newline in the file, type the name, a "=", and the meaning of the alias 
5. Save and use the command "refresh" 

To use an alias: 
Just type its name and press enter
